body_html:
./configure runs the python path provided and asks for the version from the binary.

To test that this is a bug, can you reply with the output of the following in a fresh shell without extra configuration (like sh):

  • ./configure with /usr/bin/python3 instead of the default
  • /usr/bin/python3 -c 'import sys; print(sys.version[0])'
  • /usr/bin/python -c 'import sys; print(sys.version[0])'
  • python -c 'import sys; print(sys.version[0])'
body_text:
./configure runs the python path provided and asks for the version from the binary.
To test that this is a bug, can you reply with the output of the following in a fresh shell without extra configuration (like sh):

./configure with /usr/bin/python3 instead of the default
/usr/bin/python3 -c 'import sys; print(sys.version[0])'
/usr/bin/python -c 'import sys; print(sys.version[0])'
python -c 'import sys; print(sys.version[0])'
body:
`./configure` runs the python path provided and [asks for the version from the binary](https://github.com/tensorflow/tensorflow/blob/34609f1501ad87dde6d2b2ec0dbdf794b773e008/configure.py#L177).

To test that this is a bug, can you reply with the output of the following in a fresh shell without extra configuration (like `sh`):

- `./configure` with `/usr/bin/python3` instead of the default
- `/usr/bin/python3 -c 'import sys; print(sys.version[0])'`
- `/usr/bin/python -c 'import sys; print(sys.version[0])'`
- `python -c 'import sys; print(sys.version[0])'`
